Article.ArticleTitle: Interactive effect of elevated tropospheric ozone and carbon dioxide on radiation utilisation, growth and yield of chickpea (Cicer arietinum L.).

AbstractText: An experiment was conducted in the Free Air Ozone and Carbon dioxide Enrichment (FAOCE) facility to study the impact of elevated O<sub>3</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub> and their interaction on chickpea crop (cv. Pusa-5023) in terms of phenology, biophysical parameters, yield components, radiation interception and use efficiency. The crop was exposed to elevated O<sub>3</sub> (EO:60ppb), CO<sub>2</sub> (EC:550 ppm) and their combined interactive treatment (ECO: EC+EO) during the entire growing season. Results revealed that the crop's total growth period was shortened by 10, 14 and 17 days under elevated CO<sub>2</sub>, elevated O<sub>3</sub> and the combined treatment, respectively. Compared to ambient condition, the leaf area index (LAI) under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> was higher by 4 to 28%, whilst it is reduced by 7.3 to 23.8% under elevated O<sub>3</sub>. The yield based radiation use efficiency (RUE<sub>y</sub>) was highest under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> (0.48 g MJ<sup>-1</sup>), followed by combined (0.41 g MJ<sup>-1</sup>), ambient (0.38 g MJ<sup>-1</sup>) and elevated O<sub>3</sub> (0.32 g MJ<sup>-1</sup>) treatments. Elevated O<sub>3</sub> decreased RUE<sub>y</sub> by 15.78% over ambient, and the interaction results in a 7.8% higher RUE<sub>y</sub>. The yield was 31.7% more under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and 21.9% lower in elevated O<sub>3</sub> treatment as compared to the ambient. The combined interactive treatment recorded a higher yield as compared to ambient by 9.7%. Harvest index (HI) was lowest under elevated O<sub>3</sub> (36.10%), followed by ambient (39.18%), combined (40.81%), and highest was under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> (44.18%). Chickpea showed a positive response to elevated CO<sub>2</sub> resulting a 5% increase in HI as compared to ambient condition. Our findings quantified the positive and negative impacts of elevated O<sub>3</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub> and their interaction on chickpea and revealed that the negative impacts of elevated O<sub>3</sub> can be compensated by elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in chickpea. This work promotes the understanding of crop behaviour under elevated O<sub>3</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub> and their interaction, which can be used as valuable inputs for radiation-based crop simulation models to simulate climate change impact on chickpea crop.
